title: If your tone of voice is offensive to people, how do you consciously change your tone to sound less aggressive and make it a regular way of speaking? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a very simple, yet difficult kind of question to answer… because it covers a few things going on potentially that may define “offensive” as different things to different people. So i’ll give an honest try at answering it. Lets first look at “offensive”….. Some people just have a certain type of voice or accent that can flat out be irritating just to hear them speak period….. to some. Descriptions might range from squeaky, whiny, raspy, etc. In that particular instance? I don’t think adjusting ones attitude in how they speak would even make a difference. Now another way a person can sound “offensive” is as if they are hard of hearing and are constantly telling when they speak and they don’t even realize it, or in a conversation they seem to miss reciprocal cues that allow mutual, effective two way communication and constantly seem to talk over the other person.. which may come off as rude and inconsiderate but it’s actually due to a hearing impairment. Furthermore, another way someone may be deemed offensive is because of no home training… no manners… just an outright disrespectful attitude where a person talks aggressively to anyone… with no filter, no throttle for common sense…. technically speaking an “asshole” that doesn’t know that they are a “asshole.” Now this “asshole”… can be fixed with an education in class and manners. “How to be respectful to others 101.” Because some people were never raised properly in the concept being respectful to other people. That’s a fixable ignorance with proper awareness and education. As in one should be more aware of noticing their impact and engagement upon others…. some people are simply just not good communicators or easy to talk to for the above reasons and more. Notwithstanding, if it isn’t a physical impairment or a mental impairment…. then it’s just a matter of re-educating oneself under the guidance of some constructive criticism. For an example … it’s not just enough to tell some one “Hey you’re an asshole!” But rather say .. “Hey, you know many people might think of you as an asshole whenever you say that like that and here’s the reason why……” Far too often people are the way that they are and are completely clueless about it. This is what good friends…. and good PR training is for. In short I came from an environment in truth where a person could literally lose their life…… simply by coming out of their mouth…. disrespectfully….I mean that seriously…….. or at the least you can find plenty of YOUTUBE videos right now where a person comes out of their mouth disrespectfully.. and the next thing that happens is their getting knocked out or worse. So at all times…… it’s best to be as respectful as you can to everyone. Respect should…. often beget respect. Our tone of voice, in “how“ we say something……. is just as if not more important…. than “what“ we say to each other. To address anyone…. unnecessarily with an aggressive tone…. puts them on guard….. they will feel attacked or feel like an act of intimidation is upon them… and they will respond differently often not in a respectable manner in return. So much of this can be an adjustment in attitude. Re-educating oneself with a genuine desire to communicate effectively. Being open to constructive criticism. Making the necessary adjustments to better learn how to communicate effectively. Many people will be mad at one person…. and then be angry with how they speak to everyone else….. hurting the innocent. That’s not wise to do. So it’s about compartmentalizing engagements… leave problems at work at work….. leave problems at home… at home. Make the necessary adjustment to get at what is making one angry? What are you upset about? Must you take that attitude out on everybody else except the person that made you angry? it gets complicated but the awareness is necessary.. nobody fixes anything until they can see it’s broken. I hope that you may find this information useful… (seriously not trying to be an asshole here…. :) LM Blair

That’s a very good question. Loads of ideas here. I’ll try to add something different. It is a tricky thing, because people do vary, and what works with someone may not work for another. It sounds like a good dissertation subject. :) I suppose that the trick is to solve the problem and still be “you”. I’ve been “that person” myself. For example, if I feel that I’m not being listened to, my speech gets more vehement, less pleasant, and faster, even though my usual sound is a moderate tempo and easy-going. Following that thought, do you find that this happens in particular situations, such as emotionally charged situations? Or does it happen during everyday speech? As a side note, one very unfortunate thing is that women are held to a different standard than men in such situations, especially business situations. When some man is stern and commanding in sound, that’s viewed as authoritative. When a woman does that, she’s labeled with nasty names. That’s our wonderful screwball society at work. Not much we can do about that until society catches up, I guess. Apart from that…. It sounds like people have told you that they don’t like your tone of voice. I imagine that was quite unpleasant to hear. If that’s the case, and it’s not too fraught, maybe you could ask them what they didn’t like. Also, maybe you have a trusted friend who will give you honest feedback. Another thought is to record your voice and listen to it. Does it sound good to you? To generalize a bit, as a city person, your cadence may be considerably faster than a rural person, who may find it disturbing, rightly or wrongly. It could be louder, too, as somebody amongst loads of people on a daily basis may need to project their voice to simply be heard. If it seems like that’s happening, slowing down a tad may be an interesting experiment, and trying lower volume. Different groups of people, whether by ethnicity, culture, region, nationality, etc., may have different ideas about offensiveness and politeness in speech. When one is amongst different types of people, different speaking strategies can be used, and I do this sometimes. Maybe other ideas could be tried. If it’s an emotional situation, counting to ten before a response could help, as well as taking a nice deep breath. I forget to do this myself, and sometimes it shows. On that same subject, a random idea (that might be bunk) would be to breathe deeply when talking, sort of getting a relaxed yoga-like feeling to it. Here’s a thought - if most people think you sound fine, maybe the rest of them should just get a bleeping life. :) Good luck! It’s not fun when people find us offensive!
